page.title: 13FARMING
page.content: One farm in the block is 360 acres. It has 60 acres of permanent grazing which is let to another farmer in the summer, and the rest of the farm is arable. Crops grown in 1985 were winter wheat, oil-seed rape, sugar beet, barley, and a small acreage of oats grown for seed. Late summer and autumn is the busiest part of the year. Barley and rape are harvested from late July, then wheat. Harvesting will begin as soon as the dew has dried in the morning, and continue until dusk. Fields are ploughed soon after they are harvested,as the clay soil is usually at its driest at this time,and suffers less from compacting by heavy machinery.Sugar beet is lifted from late September until Christmas. There is then a lull until the weather is open enough for spring sowing.
